entry.title: Generating and Integrating Automated Predictive Library (APL) Forecasts in a Seamless Planning Model
entry.content:
Introduction 

SAP Analytics Cloud has always been the one solution for BI, planning and predictive analytics. As such, it has powerful built-in capabilities for regression, classification and time-series forecasting. You know them as Predictive Scenarios and many of you have used them to support their planning processes. Our predictive scenarios are perfect for business users: they choose the best available algorithm for your data and explain the results while maintaining the semantics of the model throughout the process (e.g., hierarchies). With SAP Business Data Cloud and seamless planning, data scientists on the other hand can now leverage HANA’s predictive Predictive Analysis Library (PAL) and Automated Predictive Library (APL) directly on the HANA database of SAP Datasphere and nicely integrate the results into planning processes. This lets them tweak predictive models by picking and choosing the algorithm of their choice and use code instead of a UI. SAP BDC would also allow them to share data with SAP Databricks or another Databricks instance using data products if this was their preferred environment. 

This blogpost was created with @marc_daniau, a development expert for our predictive engine. We want to demonstrate the usage of HANA APL in combination with a seamless planning model and live versions. We do this using a straight-forward prediction based on actual data.  

 

High-level overview 

This is what we are working with: 

In SAP Analytics Cloud, we have a planning model deployed to an SAP Datasphere space. That makes it a seamless planning model which means that its data is not stored on the SAP Analytics Cloud database but only on the SAP Datasphere database.  

In the SAP Datasphere space, we find the planning model data and a table with actuals. We are not using an SAP BDC data product, but you surely could! 

We create our prediction directly on the underlying HANA Cloud database of SAP Datasphere. We created a DB user to access the database. There, we consume the actuals, create a stored procedure which we can trigger via a task chain, and surface the result in a view in the space. This fact data can then be added to the seamless planning model as a live version.  

 

Step-by-step 

1. Seamless planning model 

We do not cover the full creation and set-up of the model. Let’s just check out its key characteristics:  

  • It is a seamless planning model, deployed to the space Sales Planning Demo 
  • Its fact table is exposed in the SAP Datasphere space (actually, this is not decisive for the use case described here but could be useful if you want to add budget data as influence for your predictive model, for instance) 
  •  We want to create a forecast version and predict the measure SALES_REVENUE along the product and region dimension 

2. SAP Datasphere space

Again, we do not look at the creation of the space and all its artefacts. The following Actuals view is key as we extrapolate our forecast based on this data: 

  • Measures and attributes nicely match the planning model structure (which is handy for our simple demo scenario J) 
  • We excluded columns that we do not need in a projection 
  • We filtered on date as we do not want to use the entire history 

3. Setting up database access 

We are now ready to learn how to create the forecast on the HANA database. First of all, we need to set up database access.  

  • Prerequisite: Enable the SAP HANA Cloud Script Server on Your SAP Datasphere Tenant 
  • Navigate to Space Management, find your space and Edit.  
  • Navigate to Database Access and create a new user 
     
  • Name your user and make the needed settings as highlighted. Your user’s name will be a concatenation of your space name, ‘#’ and the suffix you provide here. 
     
  • Mark your user and open the database explorer. The password can be retrieved in the details of the user (information symbol).  

4. Database explorer 

Let’s first have an overview of what we are creating in the database explorer: 

 

  • We create a view that consumes the actual data from our space schema. Note the following: 
  • We concatenate Product and Region to one Entity column that we will use to segment our prediction. As we work directly on flat fact tables/views, we do not have the luxury of keeping all semantics as we have it in the SAP Analytics Cloud predictive scenarios.  

 

CREATE VIEW "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_SERIES_IN" ( "Entity", "Date", "SalesRevenue" ) AS (select   
  "Product" || '|' || "Regions" as "Entity", "Date", "SalesRevenue" 
 from  
  SALES_PLANNING_DEMO."V_Actual_Sales_Data" 
 order by 1, 2)

  • We now create the prediction task as a stored procedure.  
create procedure "APL_FORECAST_TASK" 
as BEGIN
    declare header "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.FUNCTION_HEADER";
    declare config "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.OPERATION_CONFIG_DETAILED";
	declare var_desc "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.VARIABLE_DESC_OID";   
    declare var_role "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.VARIABLE_ROLES_WITH_COMPOSITES_OID";    
    declare apl_log   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.OPERATION_LOG";      
    declare apl_sum   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.SUMMARY";   
    declare apl_indic   "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.INDICATORS";   	
    declare apl_metr "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.DEBRIEF_METRIC_OID";
    declare apl_prop "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::BASE.T.DEBRIEF_PROPERTY_OID";      

    truncate table "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_SERIES_OUT";
    truncate table "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY";
    truncate table "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_FORECAST_STATUS";
	
    :header.insert(('Oid', 'DSP APL'));
    :header.insert(('LogLevel', '2'));
    :header.insert(('MaxTasks', '4'));  --  PARALLEL TASKS

    :config.insert(('APL/SegmentColumnName', 'Entity',null)); 
    :config.insert(('APL/Horizon', '12',null));
    :config.insert(('APL/TimePointColumnName', 'Date',null));
	:config.insert(('APL/ForcePositiveForecast', 'true',null));
	:config.insert(('APL/DecomposeInfluencers', 'true',null));
	:config.insert(('APL/ApplyExtraMode', 'First Forecast with Stable Components and Residues and Error Bars',null));
	
    :var_role.insert(('Date', 'input', null, null, null));
    :var_role.insert(('SalesRevenue', 'target', null, null, null));
		
    "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.base::FORECAST_AND_DEBRIEF" (
	:header, :config, :var_desc, :var_role, 
	'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER', 'APL_SERIES_IN', 
	'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER', 'APL_SERIES_OUT', apl_log, apl_sum, apl_indic, apl_metr, apl_prop);

    insert into "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY" 
    select "Oid" as "Entity", "MAE", "MAPE"
    from "SAP_PA_APL"."sap.pa.apl.debrief.report::TimeSeries_Performance" (:apl_prop, :apl_metr)
    where "Partition" = 'Validation';
	
	insert into "SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER"."APL_FORECAST_STATUS" 
    select "OID" as "Entity", "VALUE" as "Task Status"
	from :apl_sum 
	where key = 'AplTaskStatus';
END

For our demo scenario we use the default APL forecasting method that automatically tries different hypotheses for trend, cycles and fluctuations, and eventually selects the combination that gives the best accuracy. For a faster processing on many segments, an option is to force the Exponential Smoothing method by adding to the procedure this line of code below: 

:config.insert(('APL/ForecastMethod','ExponentialSmoothing',null));

This is the code to prepare the target tables of the procedure: 

drop table APL_SERIES_OUT;
create table APL_SERIES_OUT (
 "Entity"  nvarchar(180),
 "Date" 	DATE,
 "SalesRevenue" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Trend" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Cycles" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1_lowerlimit_95%" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1_upperlimit_95%" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1ExtraPreds" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Fluctuations" DOUBLE,
 "kts_1Residues" DOUBLE
);

 

drop table APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY;
create table APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY (
 "Entity"  nvarchar(180),
 "MAE" DOUBLE,
 "MAPE" DOUBLE
);

 

drop table APL_FORECAST_STATUS;
create table APL_FORECAST_STATUS (
 "Entity"  nvarchar(180),
 "Task Status" nvarchar(180)
);
  • You can trigger this procedure manually using the command below: 
call "APL_FORECAST_TASK" ;

However, in the next chapter, we will also create a task chain in SAP Datasphere to trigger it which can be embedded in real workflows.  

  • You see we generate and write data into three different tables: 
  • The prediction result goes into our results table called APL_SERIES_OUT. This is the data that we want for our seamless planning model. The table has the concatenated entity, date and the predicted revenue. It also comes with upper and lower limit predictions (95%) as well as with fluctuations, extra predictions etc.  
     
  • Optionally, we create the table APL_FORECAST_ACCURACY to store the MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error MAE (Mean Absolute Error) per entity. You could filter on the entities you are interested in, the best/worst entities etc. or you could get the MSE (Mean Squared Error) or RMSE (Root Mean Absolute Squared Error) as well.  

  • Optionally, we create the table APL_FORECAST_STATUS where we log the prediction status per entity. All our entities were successful.  

 

5. Task chain 

Stored procedures can be executed via task chains. As such, you can execute them from the SAP Datasphere UI, schedule them or trigger them via external API. Check out the task chain documentation to learn more about prerequisites such as required roles. Soon, you should be able to trigger this API via multi actions in SAP Analytics Cloud as well.  

We must allow the execution of the stored procedure via the SAP Datasphere UI including the creation and deletion of data in the database user schema:  

CALL "DWC_GLOBAL"."GRANT_PRIVILEGE_TO_SPACE" ( 
             OPERATION => 'GRANT',  
             PRIVILEGE => 'INSERT',  
             SCHEMA_NAME => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER',  
             OBJECT_NAME => '',  
             SPACE_ID => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO');

              

CALL "DWC_GLOBAL"."GRANT_PRIVILEGE_TO_SPACE" ( 
             OPERATION => 'GRANT',  
             PRIVILEGE => 'DELETE',  
             SCHEMA_NAME => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER',  
             OBJECT_NAME => '',  
             SPACE_ID => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO');

 

CALL "DWC_GLOBAL"."GRANT_PRIVILEGE_TO_SPACE" ( 
             OPERATION => 'GRANT',  
             PRIVILEGE => 'EXECUTE',  
             SCHEMA_NAME => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO#AI_USER',  
             OBJECT_NAME => '',  
             SPACE_ID => 'SALES_PLANNING_DEMO');

Setting up task chains is simple. To add a stored procedures, you select Others and browse through the available procedures that are available for your space. Then you drag the procedure on to the canvas to add it as a task.    

You can add replication flows, transformation flows, intelligent lookups etc. to your task chains. By that, you could for instance first refresh actuals and get them into shape so you can use them for your prediction. Or, you add an email notification task to receive updates after the execution of the task chain (I did that in the example below).  

6. Consuming results in the SAP Datasphere space 

Now that we have the predictive logic to calculate and we can execute it via the SAP Datasphere UI, we of course need to consume the forecast data in the planning model. To do that, we first need the results in the SAP Datasphere space. We create a view on top of the results table. We used a graphical view but depending on your preferences and skills, you may use an SQL view instead.  

  • Pull the results table from the DB user schema in the Sources tab. 

  • Add a calculation node to split the Entity column into regions and products again. Create two calculated columns (Product and Region) and use string functions.  The functions SUBSTR_BEFORE() and SUBSTR_AFTER() can be used to split a string using the first occurence of a specified pattern (in our case '|'  as the format of our Entity column is Product|Region). 

 Expression to derive product:

SUBSTR_BEFORE(Entity,'|')

Expression to derive region:

SUBSTR_AFTER(Entity,'|')
  •  Join the standard time dimension with day granularity to derive the calendar month from the date. Standard time tables and dimensions can be generated in Space Management (link).  

  • Add a projection and only keep the columns you need in the planning model. 
    • Calendar Month 
    • SalesRevenue 
    • Product 
    • Region 
  • Make sure to expose the view for consumption and select Fact as the Semantic Usage Type.  
  • Name the view and deploy.  

7. Adding the forecast result as live version in the seamless planning model 

We now move to SAP Analytics Cloud and add the forecast result to the seamless planning model as a live version.  

  • Connect external data source. 

  • Create a version to map the data into (or use an existing un-used version). 
  • Select the view. 
  • Map the columns. 
     
  • Preview the data. You see that we have a live connection to the forecast results in SAP Datasphere. So every time that the forecast is updated, it will be reflected in the planning model in real time! 

 

What (else) can/could you do with it?  

In SAP Analytics Cloud:  

  • You can display the live version data in the model data foundation and in tables, charts, etc. in stories. 
  • You can reference the live version data in model and story calculations as well as data actions (incl. advanced formulas). 
  • You cannot write back into the referenced views (or rather their underlying tables). But, you can copy the live version data into planning versions via copy/paste in the table, data actions and version management. 

In SAP Datasphere: 

  • You can of course leverage the forecast result in your views and analytic models and compare it to actuals, budgets, etc.  
  • You can run further transformations and calculations and report on the results or use them in planning.  
  • … 

 

Which new features can improve the workflow in the future? 

We are working on a couple of features that can make this scenario even better: 

  • Push data from SAP Datasphere into the seamless planning model via task chains:  
    Live versions are awesome. But, sometimes you want to use the prediction as a proposal and then edit it. You could copy the live version data into an editable version easily (see above) but with a push of data into the planning model, you could directly bring the data into an editable forecast version. That push could be nicely added to the same task chain that triggers the APL procedure. 
  • Trigger task chains from SAP Analytics Cloud:
    Task chains shall soon offer a public API for triggering task chain runs from outside of SAP Datasphere.
    We are getting ready on the SAP Analytics Cloud side to let you call this API via API steps in multi actions. With that, you could trigger the stored procedures from SAP Analytics Cloud.  
    Some day, we may have dedicated task chain steps in multi actions to ease this cross-orchestration. We also want to enable cross-orchestration in the opposite direction.  

 

Conclusion 

In this blogpost, Marc and I demonstrated how to integrate predictive forecast results from SAP HANA APL in a seamless planning model. We combined the power of SAP Datasphere, SAP HANA and SAP Analytics Cloud to achieve that in a quite straight-forward architecture. You could achieve more complex scenarios, use PAL instead to tweak your prediction more etc. Or you could use data products from SAP BDC to get you started even quicker.  

We are looking forward to the future enhancements that shall improve such workflows and the overall integration of planning into SAP BDC! 

 

Learn More 

  • Seamless Planning - Product FAQ 
  • Seamless Planning – Live Versions 
  • SAP HANA Automated Predictive Library (APL) 
  • SAP HANA Predictive Analysis Library (PAL)  
  • SAP Analytics Cloud Predictive Scenarios

entry.title: Connecting SAP Sales Cloud V2 to a Standalone SAP Analytics Cloud - A Practical Alternative
entry.content:
The Customer Challenge

A customer approached me with what seemed like a straightforward request: "We want to analyze our SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 data in SAP Analytics Cloud."

Their situation was common for mid-sized companies adopting SAP's CX portfolio:

  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 was live and running well
  • SAP Analytics Cloud was licensed separately (not the embedded version)
  • No SAP BTP subscription yet, it wasn't part of the initial scope
  • No SAP Integration Suite same reason
  • No SAP Datasphere, they wanted to avoid another data platform

The goal was simple: import Accounts, Contacts, and Opportunities into SAC for custom dashboards that combined CX data with data from other sources

What SAP Officially Recommends

Before building anything custom, I researched SAP's official guidance. The recommended architecture for Sales Cloud V2 analytics integration involves:

  1. SAP Datasphere as a central data layer
  2. SAP Integration Suite for event-driven data replication
  3. SAP Advanced Event Mesh (optional but recommended) for resilience

SAP published a detailed two-part blog series on this: Event-Driven Data Integration from SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 to SAP Datasphere

This architecture is elegant and production-grade. It's also significant additional investment for a customer who just wants to run a few reports.

Cost Implications

The official path requires more than you might expect:

ComponentStatus for this Customer
SAP DatasphereNot licensed (€€€/month)
SAP Integration SuiteNot licensed (€€/month)
SAP BTP subscriptionNot available
Implementation effortSignificant (weeks)


For a customer with ~24,000 accounts who wants three dashboards, this felt like using a sledgehammer to crack a nut.

The Obvious First Attempt: SAC's Built-in Connectors

SAC has connectors for various SAP sources. Surely there's something for Sales Cloud?

Attempt 1: The "SAP Cloud for Customer" Connector

SAC includes a dedicated connector called "SAP Cloud for Customer" that works beautifully with the older C4C (Cloud for Customer) system. It connects to OData services like:

https://<tenant>/sap/c4c/odata/v1/c4codataapi/AccountCollection

The problem: Sales Cloud V2 is not C4C. So the OData connector won’t work:

Attempt 2: The Generic OData Connector

SAC also has a generic "OData Services" connector. Maybe that works?

The problem: Sales Cloud V2 doesn't expose OData endpoints. The APIs on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub are REST, not OData.

GET /sap/c4c/api/v1/account-service/accounts ← REST, not OData
GET /sap/c4c/api/v1/contact-service/contacts ← REST, not OData

Attempt 3: Live Connection

Sales Cloud V2 has embedded SAC capabilities. Could we establish a live connection?

The problem: The embedded analytics are designed for "embedded" use cases. Connecting a standalone SAC tenant to Sales Cloud V2 for custom reporting seems to be... let's say "not a focus area" right now.

I opened a support ticket to clarify the expected behavior and it was put in development after a little back and forth.

The Hidden Challenge: Real-Time vs. Import

At this point, I had to step back and discuss architecture with the customer.

Even if a direct connector existed, there are implications to consider:

 

ApproachProsCons
Live ConnectionAlways current dataQuery performance depends on source; cannot combine with other data sources easily
Import ConnectionFast queries; can blend with other sourcesData has latency; storage costs

The customer wanted to combine Sales Cloud V2 data with SAP S/4HANA data in the same dashboard. This essentially requires import connections for both sources, plus a data model in SAC that joins them.

Real-time was never really an option as they needed data at rest in SAP Analytics Cloud 

The Solution: A Lightweight REST-to-OData Proxy

Since the customer had:

  • No appetite for SAP Datasphere
  • No CPI license
  • A clear, limited scope (three entity types)
  • Tolerance for daily data refresh (not real-time)

I proposed building a thin proxy server that:

  1. Authenticates with Sales Cloud V2
  2. Fetches data via REST APIs
  3. Transforms responses to OData format
  4. Exposes endpoints that SAC can consume natively

Architecture

This sounds straightforward... until you start building it...

Challenge 1: The 999 vs. 1000 Mismatch

This one deserves its own section because it’s so unexpected.

SAP Sales Cloud V2 REST APIs have a maximum page size of 999 records. You can request $top=999, but not more.

SAP Analytics Cloud OData import has a minimum batch size of 1000 records.

Yes, you read that correctly. The source maxes out at 999. The target starts at 1000. I'll admit I stared at the logs for longer than I'd like to admit before I realized what was happening. The first 999 records imported perfectly. Then nothing. It took me a while to connect that SAC was waiting for a 1000-record batch that would never arrive.

The Solution

The proxy implements on-demand parallel fetching:

async function fetchAllRecords(entityType: string): Promise<any[]> {
  // Get first page to determine total count
  const firstPage = await fetchFromSalesCloud(entityType, {
    $top: 999,
    $skip: 0
  });
  
  if (firstPage.value.length < 999) {
    // All records fit in first page
    return firstPage.value;
  }
  
  // Calculate remaining pages and fetch in parallel
  const totalEstimate = firstPage.totalCount || 10000;
  const remainingPages = Math.ceil((totalEstimate - 999) / 999);
  
  const pagePromises = Array.from({ length: remainingPages }, (_, i) => 
    fetchFromSalesCloud(entityType, {
      $top: 999,
      $skip: 999 * (i + 1)
    })
  );
  
  const results = await Promise.all(pagePromises);
  return [firstPage.value, ...results.map(r => r.value)].flat();
}

The proxy fetches pages in parallel (not sequentially), caches the combined result, and serves it to SAC in appropriately sized batches. The cache has a configurable TTL (e.g., 1 hour) and automatically refreshes on the next request after expiry.

Challenge 2: Nested Objects and Flattening

Sales Cloud V2 returns nicely structured JSON with nested objects:

{
  "value": [{
    "accountId": "A001",
    "accountName": "ACME Corp",
    "primaryContact": {
      "contactId": "C001",
      "firstName": "John",
      "lastName": "Doe"
    },
    "addresses": [
      { "type": "BILL_TO", "city": "Berlin" },
      { "type": "SHIP_TO", "city": "Munich" }
    ]
  }]
}

SAC’s OData importer cannot handle this. The SAP Help documentation states clearly: Embedded Complex types are not supported.

The Solution

The proxy must flatten nested structures into separate entity sets:

/odata/Accounts         → Flat account records
/odata/Contacts         → Flat contact records  
/odata/AccountAddresses → One row per address, linked by accountId

Challenge 3: REST APIs Behave Differently Than OData

Coming from the OData world, I expected certain conventions:

  • $filter for filtering
  • $select for field selection
  • $expand for related entities
  • Standardized metadata endpoint

Sales Cloud V2 REST APIs have their own conventions:

  • Different query parameter syntax
  • No $metadata endpoint
  • Pagination via custom headers or response properties

The proxy needs to translate between these worlds, implementing just enough OData semantics to satisfy SAC’s importer.

Challenge 4: The $skip 10,000 Limit

Just when you think you’ve handled pagination, there’s another surprise waiting for datasets with more than 10,000 records.

Sales Cloud V2 returns an error if $skip is 10,000 or greater.

// This works
GET /accounts?$top=999&$skip=9000  ✅

// This fails
GET /accounts?$top=999&$skip=10000  ❌ Error!

So even if you’ve cleverly worked around the 999 page size limit, you hit a wall at record 10,001. Simple offset-based pagination ($skip) just stops working.

The Solution

Instead of offset-based pagination, the proxy uses keyset pagination with $skiptoken:

// src/constants.ts
export const SC_MAX_SKIP = 10000;

// When approaching the skip limit, switch to skiptoken
async function fetchWithKeysetPagination(entityType: string): Promise<any[]> {
  const allRecords: any[] = [];
  let nextLink: string | null = buildInitialUrl(entityType);
  
  while (nextLink) {
    const response = await fetch(nextLink);
    const data = await response.json();
    
    allRecords.push(...data.value);
    
    // Use the skiptoken from the response for next page
    nextLink = data['@odata.nextLink'] || null;
  }
  
  return allRecords;
}

Keyset pagination uses a token (typically based on the last record’s ID or timestamp) rather than a numeric offset. This approach:

  • Has no upper limit on the number of records
  • Is actually more performant than large offsets
  • Is the pattern SAP recommends for large datasets

If you have more than 10,000 records in any entity, you must use $skiptoken-based pagination. Simple $skip won’t cut it.

Implementation Notes

Technology Choice

I built the proxy with:

  • Node.js + Fastify: Lightweight, fast, excellent TypeScript support
  • On-demand caching: No scheduled jobs; cache fills dynamically on first request
  • Docker deployment: Runs on any container platform (I use Coolify on a VPS)

This is a production-ready setup. The proxy has been running reliably for the customer with no issues.

Smart Caching: On-Demand Parallel Fetching

Rather than running scheduled batch jobs, the proxy uses an on-demand approach:

  1. First page served instantly: When SAC requests data, the proxy immediately returns the first page (up to 999 records) from Sales Cloud V2
  2. Parallel fetching in background: While SAC processes the first page, the proxy fetches remaining pages in parallel
  3. Cache populated for subsequent requests: By the time SAC requests page 2, the data is already cached
async function handleODataRequest(req: Request): Promise<Response> {
  // Check cache first
  if (cache.has(entityType) && !cache.isExpired(entityType)) {
    return serveFromCache(entityType, req.query);
  }
  
  // Fetch first page immediately
  const firstPage = await fetchPage(entityType, 0, 999);
  
  // Start parallel fetching of remaining pages (non-blocking)
  fetchRemainingPagesInBackground(entityType, firstPage.totalCount);
  
  // Return first page immediately
  return formatAsOData(firstPage);
}

This approach has several advantages:

  • No unnecessary background jobs: Data is only fetched when actually needed
  • Fast initial response: User doesn’t wait for full dataset
  • Self-healing cache: Expired cache automatically refreshes on next request

Optional: Deploying to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry

If you already have a BTP subscription with available credits, deploying there can make sense. You’re using infrastructure you’re already paying for. The migration is straightforward:

Standalone Setup Cloud Foundry Setup

Environment variables for credentialsDestination Service binding
In-memory cachePostgreSQL Hyperscaler Option (free tier available)
Direct HTTP endpointXSUAA + AppRouter

Why PostgreSQL if you move to BTP?

On a single-container deployment (VPS e.g. with Coolify), in-memory caching works perfectly. But Cloud Foundry typically runs multiple app instances for high availability. If you need persistence across instances, PostgreSQL Hyperscaler Option is the lightweight choice. It has a free tier (since November 2025) and requires no additional management.

The additional effort for Cloud Foundry deployment is roughly:

  • Add mta.yaml with service bindings (~1 hour)
  • Configure Destination Service for Sales Cloud V2 credentials (~30 min)
  • Add XSUAA for authentication (~1 hour)
  • Test and deploy (~2 hours)

Total: Less than one additional day if you decide BTP is the right fit.

Don’t just default to BTP just because it’s SAP. Evaluate what you already have and what makes sense for your situation. A €5/month VPS running Docker might be exactly right for your use case.

OData Response Format

SAC expects OData V2or V4 responses. The minimum viable format:

{
  "d": {
    "results": [
      { "AccountID": "A001", "AccountName": "ACME Corp", ... },
      { "AccountID": "A002", "AccountName": "Globex", ... }
    ]
  }
}

Plus a $metadata endpoint returning EDMX that describes your entity types.

Authentication

Sales Cloud V2 supports:

  • Basic Authentication (simplest for server-to-server)
  • OAuth 2.0 (more secure, recommended for production)

The proxy stores credentials securely and handles token refresh for OAuth.

Results

After implementing the proxy:

  • SAC successfully imports Accounts, Contacts, and Opportunities
  • Data refreshes nightly via scheduled import
  • Customer can blend CX data with S/4HANA data in unified dashboards
  • No additional SAP platform licenses required
  • Total implementation time: ~2 days

When This Approach Makes Sense

The right solution depends on what you have and what you need. Here’s how I think about it:

A lightweight proxy makes sense when:

  • Limited scope (specific entities, not the entire data model)
  • Import/batch refresh is acceptable (not real-time requirements)
  • You don’t have Datasphere or CPI licensed and don’t need them for other use cases
  • You want to validate the integration quickly before investing in bigger infrastructure

Datasphere + CPI makes sense when:

  • You need event-driven, near real-time data replication
  • You’re integrating many entity types with complex relationships
  • You already have Datasphere or CPI licensed then use what you’re paying for
  • You have a broader data strategy where Datasphere is the central hub anyway

The key question: What do you already have, and does this use case justify adding more?

SAP’s platforms are excellent, no question! But sometimes a focused solution that solves exactly your problem is better than pulling in the big guns for a straightforward requirement.

Lessons Learned

1. Don’t Assume SAP Products Integrate Seamlessly

Sales Cloud V2 and SAC are both modern SAP cloud products. The integration gap exists because V2’s move away from OData wasn’t accompanied by a new native SAC connector (yet).

2. Check API Patterns Before Committing to Architecture

The shift from OData to REST in Sales Cloud V2 is documented, but easy to miss if you’re coming from C4C experience. Always verify on api.sap.com.

3. Test with Realistic Data Volumes

The 999/1000 mismatch only surfaces with more than 999 records. Demo systems with 50 accounts work fine. Production breaks.

4. Use What You Have, Validate What You Need

The official architecture is powerful. But if you don’t already have Datasphere and CPI licensed, ask yourself: does this specific use case justify adding them? Sometimes a focused solution that solves exactly your problem is the right call. You can always scale up later if requirements grow.

What’s Next?

I’ve published a reference implementation on GitHub that demonstrates the core patterns:

  • REST-to-OData transformation
  • Parallel fetching with caching
  • The 999→1000 batch bridging logic
  • Keyset pagination with $skiptoken for large datasets (>10k records)

👉 GitHub: SAP Sales Cloud V2 OData Proxy

A note on scope: The repository shows how the solution works, but doesn’t include everything from my production implementation. Some aspects are tied to specific client configurations that I can’t share. If you’re facing a similar challenge and want help getting to production faster, feel free to reach out.

If you’ve built something similar or found a better approach I’d love to hear about it in the comments.

entry.title: From insight to impact: The future of planning with SAP agent driven experiences
entry.content:
Planning is evolving.  Fast.
Static models and endless spreadsheets aren’t enough anymore.

Join us for “From insight to impact: The future of planning with SAP agent-driven experiences” and get a first look at how SAP is reshaping planning and SAP EPM with intelligent agents.

In this session, we’ll move quickly through what matters:
- Why SAP is shifting toward outcomes-driven, agent-based planning.

- What the new flexible simulation layer means for speed, freedom, and governance in SAP Analytics Cloud.

You’ll see concrete partner use cases—workforce planning, cash flow, consolidation variance analysis—and, just as important, where the commercial opportunities are. Advisory services. Extensions. Accelerators. Packaged solutions.  The kind customers are actively asking for.

We’ll also connect these innovations to what’s ahead on SAP’s roadmap and key themes leading up to SAP Sapphire.  Short version?  This is where planning is going, and partners who understand it early will lead the conversation.

#SAP #SAPBTP #SAPPartners #SAPEPM #SAPAnalyticsCloud #PlanningInnovation #SAPSapphire

entry.title: Understanding Known Limitations of Calculations Feature in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
entry.content:
Overview of the Collective KBA

With SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), users can create flexible reporting through the use of 'story calculation', however, it is important to note that not all story calculations are created equally; there are limitations, set by the design of story calculations, which may impact the way in which the calculation interacts with other variables, such as filters, hierarchies, drill states, types of data, and data model structure.
In order to ensure you understand how the calculation functions, we have put together an extensive resource that describes all of these conditions in detail.

3702507 — Known Limitations and By-Design Behaviors of Calculation Features in SAP Analytics Cloud (Collective KBA)

The aim of the Combined KBA is to provide a detailed perspective regarding the limitations and anticipated performance of the calculations that occur on the Story level in SAC. This will provide a way for users to recognize where some functions/operations, etc. may not work as they expect due to the way in which the calculation engine has been designed.

Purpose of the Collective KBA

The intent of the KBA is to present a transparent overview of the calculation boundaries in SAC so that report designers and analytics teams can plan and validate their work with realistic expectations. It outlines:

  • where specific functions are supported,

  • where particular data types are restricted,

  • how calculations respond to filtering and drill operations,

  • and which behaviors are determined by the design of the underlying analytical engine.

The KBA only provides clarification of capabilities. It does not offer alternative approaches, workarounds, or modeling techniques. The main goal is to make these types of limitations clear and easily accessible.

Looking ahead

SAP will continue enhancing Story Calculations and the overall SAC experience. As features evolve, this collective KBA will serve as a living reference—updated as new capabilities are delivered or design boundaries change.

If a feature is required for business operations, user may submit an enhancement request through the standard SAP Influence channel. Refer to the KBA: 2424376 - How to create an enhancement request for SAP Analytics Cloud?

Your feedback, questions, and real-world scenarios are part of what helps shape this clarity. If you encounter behaviors that feel inconsistent or unclear, please continue to raise them. They help us improve not only the product but the guidance we provide.

entry.title: Introducing the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Hi-Fi UI Kit
entry.content:
Focus of this blog:

  • Introduction
  • How the UI Kit is set up
  • How to get the UI Kit
  • How to use the UI Kit
  • Essential Ressources

 

Introduction

The new SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Hi-Fi UI Kit is a high-fidelity Figma kit specifically designed for creating dashboards in SAP Analytics Cloud Stories. It closely reflects Stories UI elements and is based on the SAP Fiori Morning Horizon theme.

The UI Kit includes ready-to-use dashboard templates with placeholder or example data, charts, and other UI controls. Designers can easily switch between templates, swap visualization types, and adapt dashboards as requirements evolve. This accelerates the design process while supporting a seamless transition from mock-ups to implementation and ensuring consistent results across projects.

👉 Download the UI Kit from GitHub

 

 

 

Why Use the SAC Dashboard Hi-Fi UI Kit?

  • Efficiency: Reduce repetitive design efforts with pre-built components, saving time and resources.
  • High-Fidelity Mockups: Design detailed and realistic dashboards that closely reflect the SAP Analytics Cloud capabilities.
  • Consistency: Adhere to established design standards to produce a cohesive look across various dashboards, enhancing overall user experience.

 

 

How the UI Kit is set up

The UI Kit consists of three pages for easy navigation and use.

The first page, “📓 Cover“, is a UI Kit overview that includes a cover, and a slide explaining the purpose and usage of the UI Kit, as well as semantic versioning.

"Cover" Page of the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Hi-Fi UI Kit

The second page, “✏️ Analytical Pages”, provides dashboard templates. Depending on the purpose of your dashboard, you can choose to use different BI page types, or start with an empty page to design your dashboard from scratch.

"Analytical Pages" page of the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Hi-Fi UI Kit

The third page, “✏️ Components”, contains all other assets: UI elements and controls, containers and different chart types available in SAP Analytics Cloud Stories.

"Components" page of the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Hi-Fi UI Kit

 

How to get the UI Kit

  1. Navigate to the "SAC Fiori Horizon Theme" folder on GitHub.

  2. Open the file "SAC_Hi-Fi_Dashboard_UI_Kit.fig".
    Open the "SAC Dashboard Hi-Fi UI Kit" Figma File from GitHub
  3. Click on the Download button.
    Download the "SAC Dashboard Hi-Fi UI Kit" Figma File from GitHub

  4. Open the downloaded file in Figma. Choose a destination folder, and you're ready to go.

 

 

How to use the UI Kit

After importing the file, we suggest making the UI Kit available within your company's Figma space. This allows you to utilize Figma’s Library feature effectively. Depending on your settings, this setup enables either just your immediate team or your entire organization to access the UI Kit via the asset panel, fostering seamless collaboration and ensuring consistent design practices across your teams.
To share a UI Kit, head to the File Settings, and click on “Publish Library...”. Choose the components you wish to include and decide who should have access to the UI Kit. Then click on "Publish" to complete the process.


Note: This feature is not available if the file has been moved to your Drafts.

"Publish library..." menu option in Figma

You can now incorporate the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Hi-Fi UI Kit into your files via the libraries dialog, making all components conveniently accessible from the assets panel.

If you prefer not to publish the UI Kit internally, you can easily copy and paste the components into your own design files or use them as local assets.

 

 

Are you ready to transform your dashboard design process?

Then download the SAC Dashboard Hi-Fi UI Kit from GitHub and get started today!

 

Essential Ressources

SAC Fiori Horizon Theme folder on GitHub

Dashboard Design Best-Practices

How to Design Low-Fidelity Dashboards with the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud compass in Q1 2026 - New Use Cases, Enhanced Workflow
entry.content:
2026 is going to be an exciting year for compass! For fans of Monte Carlo Simulation and scenario modelling in SAP Analytics Cloud, we shall kick the year off with three highly requested enhancements for Q1:

  1. Supporting AVG excl. NULL and AVG incl. unbooked for drivers
  2. Enabling simulation from dashboards with complex filters
  3. Enabling changing of target settings after simulation creation

Let me walk you through them:

 

AVG excl. NULL and AVG incl. unbooked for drivers

Previously, users were only able to model the uncertainty of key drivers with SUM aggregation or SUM exception aggregation. Even though this applies for most key drivers, users wishing to simulate with averages were left out of the game. The new support of AVG excl. NULL and AVG incl. unbooked for drivers will open the door now to simulations with average prices, average discount, average hours or any KPI which should not be summed up to reflect accurate performance assessment. This means that simulation for use cases such sales promotions or energy expenses etc. are now possible.  
(If you are unsure about the differences between the different AVG variants, check out this great blog from Alecsandra Dimofte.)


Before the enhancement, key drivers modelled with AVG excl. NULL or incl. unbooked will be blocked from simulation. 


Now users will be able to model uncertainties for key drivers modelled with AVG excl. NULL or incl. unbooked.

 

Enabling simulation from dashboards with complex filters

In the past, complex filters applied on the story, page or table level would block the creation of compass simulations directly from the story table. These complex filters include:

  • Attribute
  • Range
  • Exclude
  • Advanced filter

With the latest enhancement, the restriction is lifted and users could directly create a compass simulation right off the dashboard even with this setup. Dashboard creators, especially those dependent on time range filters or exclude filter for ease of selection, will benefit from the flexibility this feature brings to their story design to provide end users with a direct trigger for compass simulation. Take note that the complex filters applied will be displayed as read-only in compass though. Users are free to simulate right away in compass or to substitute the complex filters with something simpler before proceeding, if preferred.

Range filters and other complex filters will no longer block the direct trigger of a compass simulation from a story table. 

 

Enabling changing of target settings after simulation creation

Before Q1 2026, it was not possible to make adjustments to a compass simulation target setting once a scenario has been created. Any changes to the target setting after simulation creation would require manual removal of existing scenarios, as it would be a change in the simulation calculation. 
With the latest enhancement, the workflow has become more flexible. Users can change the target settings at any point in time. After applying the changes, the prior simulation results of private scenarios will be discarded (as the prior calculation will differ from that of the current target settings), but the driver value configurations will be retained. Users seeking to simulate impact on another similar target KPI will benefit from the ability to continue right away without having to set up identical assumptions for common drivers again.
Public scenarios, on the other hand, will be marked as invalid, but both results and driver value configurations will be retained, in case there is a need to archive past simulations despite the difference in target settings. 

 

Simulation target settings can be changed now even after scenario creation. Driver value configurations will be retained in the private scenarios.

 

With these three new enhancements in Q1 2026, compass users will experience more flexibility in handling, with better re-use of assumption modelling efforts, and more variety in the spectrum of possible drivers.

As usual, we are always on the look out for areas where compass could be sharpened even further. Have an opinion here? Do tell us what you think in the influence portal! In fact, our first feature in Q1 2026 was inspired by the a topic raised by @David_Nicolay_ . Thank you and do keep them coming!

entry.title: What’s New on My Metrics 2026 Q1 QRC: Schedule a Metrics Report
entry.content:
In my last blog post, I announced the release of scheduled Metrics Reports for 2026 Q1 QRC, and now it’s time to take a closer look at how they help you stay on top of your data.

Keeping an eye on performance metrics is essential but manually checking them can quickly become time-consuming. With scheduled Metrics Reports in My Metrics, you can stay informed without the extra effort. By subscribing to a metrics report, you’ll automatically receive updates on changes in your selected metrics, delivered on a daily, weekly, or monthly schedule. Simply choose the recurrence pattern that works best for you and let the insights come to you right when you need them.

Below is a practical guide to what the feature does, how to set it up, common options, and tips for best results.

Why Subscribe to a Metrics Report?

Subscribing to a metrics report lets you receive regular, automated updates on metric changes without having to manually check stories. It ensures that teams and stakeholders get consistent snapshots of what has changed since the previous report, while giving you control over the delivery cadence and recipients, so insights arrive exactly when they’re most useful.

What You Need Before You Start 

  • Access to My Metrics and permission to create subscriptions (check your role settings).
  • If you want recurrence based on working days, you must have a working day calendar defined in the underlying model. For details, see Use a Working Day Calendar for Your Series.
  • Only metrics that come from tunnel connection type models are supported in the report (this connection allows controlled exposure of data outside the corporate network). For more information, see Live Data Connections to SAP S/4HANA.
  • This feature is only available in SAP Analytics Cloud tenants running in the Cloud Foundry environment (not available in the Neo environment).

Quick Step-by-Step Setup

  1. Open the metrics list you want to subscribe to in My Metrics.
  2. In list view, choose More (the ••• / menu) and pick Subscribe to Metrics Report.
  3. In the creation dialog, enter a Subscription Name (mandatory) and a Description (recommended). Note: the name can contain only letters and numbers no special characters. 
  4. Click Next to choose the schedule.
  5. Define the recurrence pattern: Day, Week, or Month. If you use Working Day(s), pick the model that contains your working day calendar:
    • Day
      • Choose Day(s) or Working Day(s) and enter the frequency number (e.g., every 2 days).
      • If you choose Working Day(s), select the model and calendar to define non-working days
    • Week
      • Set the number of weeks between reports.
      • Choose one or more weekdays to run the report, or select Working Day and pick an ordinal working day (first, second, third, fourth, or last) from the calendar.
      • When using Working Day, select the appropriate model and calendar if more than one is available. 
    • Month
      • Day option: specify a day number (1–31). If the month has fewer days than the number you entered, the report runs on the month’s last day.
      • Working Day option: enter a frequency number or choose an ordinal working day (first, second, third, fourth, or last) of the month; select the model/calendar if required.
      • You can also schedule by “nth weekday” (for example, the second Tuesday of each month).
      • Examples: entering -2 schedules the report for the second-to-last day of the month; entering 31 schedules it on the month’s last day. 
  6. Set the planned start date and time and when the recurrence should end (by end date or number of occurrences).
  7. Click Next and add at least one recipient in the Distribution List. You can select existing users or teams.
  8. Optionally uncheck “Send email notifications” if you prefer in-app notifications onlybelow an example of an email notification of a Metrics Report:                                                                                                 
  9. Save to create the subscription.

Other Important Details and Limitations

  • Each metrics report can include up to 15 metrics.
  • The report only includes metrics that have changed since their last recorded value, this focuses recipients on recent movement.
  • Sent reports are also accessible from in-app notifications.
  • If you set recurrence on working day calendars, no report is sent on non-working days defined by that calendar.

Manage subscriptions

Manage Subscriptions lets recipients control how they interact with a metrics report and lets owners copy, edit, or delete subscriptions. Recipients can copy a subscription or change their notification settings; only the subscription owner can edit or delete it. You can also preview subscription details from the Manage Subscriptions dialog. Note that you need the correct permissions to perform these actions.

Accessing and filtering subscriptions

  • Open the metrics list in My Metrics, then choose More → Manage Subscriptions.
  • Use the filter to show Active Subscriptions (default) or switch to All Subscriptions to see inactive ones as well. This helps you quickly find the subscription you want to manage.

Copying a subscription

  • Select a subscription in the Manage Subscriptions dialog and choose Copy Subscription.
  • When you copy a subscription you duplicate its details but can change schedule or recipients. You become the owner of the new copy and it is independent of the original.

Modifying your notification settings

Recipients can mute or resume notifications for a subscription without affecting others. Steps:

  • Open the subscription, choose Notification Settings, then pick:
    • Resume Notifications
    • Mute Until: select a date and time to pause notifications until then
    • Mute All Scheduled Reports
  • Save changes. Your choices apply only to your account and won’t change other recipients’ settings.

Editing a subscription (owner only)

Owners can edit name, description, schedule, and distribution list. Steps:

  • Open Manage Subscriptions, select the subscription, choose Edit Subscription, make changes, and save.
  • Note: changing a subscription may trigger a new report schedule; recipients will be affected by edits.

Deleting a subscription (owner only)

  • Owners can delete one or more subscriptions from the Manage Subscriptions dialog.
  • Deletion removes all recipients and cancels scheduled reports. Confirm deletion in the warning dialog to proceed.

Previewing subscription details

  • In Manage Subscriptions, select a subscription to view its details (description, schedule, end date, owner, distribution list).
  • Use Preview to verify settings before copying, editing, or deleting.

Best Practices

Use descriptive subscription names in the Description field to clearly communicate the purpose and intended audience, since the subscription name itself supports only alphanumeric characters. Before rolling it out broadly, test the subscription with a small group of recipients to validate the timing and content. If your reports depend on working days, make sure the model’s working day calendar is correctly configured and that the appropriate calendar is selected when multiple options are available. Finally, choose notification channels thoughtfully, use in-app notifications for teams working primarily in SAC, and enable email notifications for external stakeholders or wider visibility.

You can quickly find and act on the correct subscriptions by using filters, making it easier to manage them efficiently. If you need similar reports, you can copy an existing subscription without changing the original setup. Notifications can be muted temporarily when a report is sent too frequently and resumed later as needed. To prevent confusion, owners should clearly communicate any edits or deletions to recipients. If management options are not visible, it’s important to verify permissions, as available actions depend on assigned roles.

Troubleshooting Tips

  • If recipients don’t receive reports, confirm you’re on a Cloud Foundry tenant and that recipients’ email addresses or user accounts are correct.
  • If a metric you expect is missing, check that it’s based on a tunnel connection type model and that it changed since the last report.
  • If the schedule doesn’t behave as expected with working days, review the model’s working day calendar and the selected calendar if multiple calendars are maintained.
  • If you can’t edit or delete a subscription, confirm you are the owner and have the required role.
  • If notifications don’t change after updating settings, re-open Manage Subscriptions to confirm your saved preferences.
  • If recipients stop receiving reports after edits, check the distribution list and schedule settings.

Wrapping Up

Subscribing to a metrics report in My Metrics is a simple way to keep stakeholders informed about metric changes with flexible scheduling and notification options. With attention to the working day settings and model selection, you can align report delivery to business calendars and avoid unnecessary messages on non-working days.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - Consolidated Error Messages in SAC Story Designer
entry.content:
An Efficiency Boost for SAC Story Designers: The New Consolidated Info Panel with the 2026.Q1 (2026.01) Release

Hello fellow SAC Story Designers,

Anyone who has already worked with the new "Model Repointing" feature knows how powerful it is. It offers enormous flexibility, but it also brings with it a challenge: after repointing a model, there is a significant risk that objects in the story will "break" - be it due to unmapped bindings, changed hierarchies, or other inconsistencies.

Previously, this meant one had to tediously navigate through every page and widget to re-establish confidence that the dashboard was in a proper, consumable state. This process was not only time-consuming but also prone to error.

For exactly this scenario, and similar ones, a decisive improvement has been introduced within the Story Design Time: the new, consolidated Info Panel. It is designed to become your central point of control for quality assurance.

The Old Way: Fragmented Information

Let us remember: Issues and recommendations were displayed in various places:

  • Critical errors (for example, a broken data binding) often appeared as individual toast messages or small icons on the widget itself.
  • Performance recommendations were somewhat hidden in a separate popup or in tooltips.

The result was a fragmented overview where one had to actively hunt for problems and could easily miss something.

The New Way: One Panel for Everything

The new Info Panel, which you can access via the icon in the top toolbar, breaks with this fragmentation. It consolidates all relevant messages in one location, giving you a clear and immediate overview of your story's health.

 

Caption: The new, consolidated Info Panel with its 'Issues', 'Performance Recommendations', and 'Scripting Errors' tabs.

Let us look at the decisive improvements in more detail:

The "Issues" Tab: The New Core Component

The most important new area is the "Issues" tab. Here, all asset-related problems are centrally collected and intelligently structured:

  • Clear Categorization: The messages can be filtered by severity (Error, Warning, Info) and are color-coded, so you see immediately what is critical.
  • Logical Structure: The list is grouped hierarchically by page and widget. You can see at a glance which chart on which page is affected.

Typical issues that you will find here are, for example:

  • Missing Input Control: A control element was deleted that is required by a chart.
  • Invalid Calculation: A calculation is no longer valid because it depends on another, missing calculation.

Integrated Performance and Scripting Insights

Next to the "Issues" tab, you find the familiar sections, which are now, however, seamlessly integrated:

  • Performance Recommendations: The proactive tips for optimizing widget performance are now also part of this central panel. Consequently, you have performance and functional issues in one view. Please check also our separate blogpost on this topic SAP Business Data Cloud - Performance Recommendations for Story Designers
  • Scripting Errors: For all who work in "Advanced Mode," scripting errors are also consolidated here, which simplifies the debugging of complex interactions considerably.

The Concrete Value for Your Daily Workflow

  • Security after Model Repointing: Instead of a manual search, you simply open the Info Panel and receive a complete list of all problems that resulted from the repointing.
  • Significant Time Savings in Debugging: The direct action links ("Open Builder Panel") reduce the click paths and search effort to a minimum.
  • Increased Story Quality: You will no longer overlook warnings or "smaller" problems and can therefore ensure a consistently high quality of your dashboards.
  • A More Efficient Workflow: All information relevant to the story's health is bundled in one place. No more jumping between different menus and views is necessary.

Conclusion

The new, consolidated Info Panel is more than just a cosmetic update. It is a fundamentally improved tool that directly addresses the pain points of us, the story designers. It proves its value especially in scenarios like Model Repointing, by helping us to quickly and reliably maintain control over complex stories.

It is a small but highly effective step towards a cleaner and more efficient design process.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - Management of Classic Stories Before Deprecation
entry.content:
Targeted Management of Classic Stories Before Deprecation with the 2026.Q1 (2026.02) Release

Hello everyone,

As many of you know, a significant technical transition is on the horizon for SAP Analytics Cloud: with the Q2 2026 release, "Classic Stories" will be officially deprecated. From this point on, it will no longer be possible to open or edit stories based on the old stack. The path forward is the conversion of this content to the "Optimized Story" format.

To support you in this process, we have previously provided tools that identify which Classic Stories are still actively in use. This approach of targeted conversion has helped many of you to set priorities (you can read more about this in our blog post on Efficient Migration of SAC Classic Stories: Focusing on the Essentials).

However, based on your feedback, we are now taking this a significant step further. Instead of just focusing on stories that are in use, we're now giving you the tools to get a complete overview and proactively clean up your system.

What's New? Three Key Enhancements for Your System Management

To make the transition as smooth as possible, we have specifically enhanced three areas of SAP Analytics Cloud:

1. A Complete, Exportable List of All Classic Stories

In the System > Overview > Content area, you will now find a new, comprehensive table. This table lists all Classic Stories present in your system—regardless of whether they have been used recently or not. The key advantage: this list is fully exportable. You can easily load the data into Excel or another tool to sort, filter, and align with business departments.

2. Targeted Deletion of Classic Stories in Housekeeping

A clean system is a performant system. We have enhanced the System > Overview > Housekeeping area to allow you to specifically filter for Classic Stories and delete them directly, even in bulk. This builds upon the existing housekeeping functionalities and provides you with a powerful tool for system hygiene. (For a general introduction to this topic, you can refer to our Efficient Data Maintenance in SAP Analytics Cloud System Overview - Housekeeping.)

 

 

3. Enhanced Metadata for Custom Analyses

For those who want to perform deeper analyses or build their own monitoring dashboards, we have enhanced the underlying data model, known as the 'Resource' model. This model is part of the standard monitoring content that is automatically updated with every system update. You can find this content under the path Files > System > Common > SAC Content.

Our recommendation is to use the standard dashboards provided there to track the progress of your migration efforts.

However, if you wish to build your own analyses or tables to specifically list Classic Stories, you can do so directly on the 'Resource' data model. To get a precise list, apply the following filters to the data source:

  • Resource Version: CLASSIC
  • Object Type: STORY
  • Resource Subtype: (No Value)

 

These filters ensure that you are exclusively looking at Classic Stories and not other object types or subtypes, such as bookmarks, in your analysis.

A Recommended Workflow

  1. Inventory: Export the complete list of Classic Stories from the System > Overview > Content area.
  2. Analysis & Decision: Go through the list and classify each story: Convert or Delete?
  3. Execution:
    1. Convert the necessary stories to the Optimized Story experience.
    2. Use the new feature in Housekeeping to remove the obsolete stories.
  4. Monitoring: Keep track of your progress, either with the standard content found under Files > System > Common > SAC Content or with your own custom analysis.

Summary

The Q2 2026 deadline is set. With a complete overview, targeted deletion capabilities, and enhanced metadata, you now have full control over the process. We recommend starting to familiarize yourself with these new tools early to ensure a smooth transition and to start the future with a clean system.
